subject: Re: [junit] Ant batchtest vs Test suite for prioritization

messageBody:
Emmanuele,

I think that the decision to understand and prioritize your tests will
make a bigger impact than the method you use to do so. Myself, I like
to gather tests into Java-level suite classes, because these can be
reused in ant, Eclipse, maven, etc.

One advantage of ant is that you can fail fast, deciding that if suite
A fails, don't even bother running suite B. Also, sometimes the build
system or political structure of a team can make it easier to edit XML
files than Java, in which case the ant file might make sense.

Good luck,

David

On Tue, Apr 28, 2009 at 6:03 AM, esordini <emmanuele.sordini@...> wrote:
> Dear all,
> I find myself faced with the following issue. I've been assigned to
> a new project where I have a group of Junit test classes (around
> 150). My aim is to setup a fully automated test environment
> starting on the current project status. I was thinking of using
> Ant as the the first step, and then moving to some continuous
> integration tool further down the line.
>
> I see two main outstanding problems:
>
> 1) My test hierarchy is made up of a heterogeneous set of classes,
> some of which are purely stand-alone classes (i.e. I have to
> manually launch them), while some others are grouped into
> test suites.
>
> 2) Test case complexity is very wide, ranging from very simple
> (and fast) ones to more complicated ones than can take hours to
> complete.
>
> So I was wondering what is the best tradeoff between prioritizing
> tests at code level (i.e. with Test Suites) vs. at script level
> (i.e. by specifying the desired order in an Ant batchtest task).
>
> Any help on this issue will be greatly appreciated.
>
> Best regards
> Emmanuele Sordini
